title: Conservation of energy - two mass-spring systems

content.question: Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> of mass <math alttext="m sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is suspended vertically from Spring <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> with spring constant <math alttext="k sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. With the spring at its unstretched length, the block is released from rest. When the block stops momentarily after falling a distance <math alttext="y sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, the Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>-Spring <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> system has mechanical energy <math alttext="E sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> of mass <math alttext="m sub 2 is greater than m sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is suspended by Spring <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> with spring constant <math alttext="k sub 2 is greater than k sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. The block is released from rest with the spring at its unstretched length. When the block stops momentarily after falling a distance <math alttext="y sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, the Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>-Spring <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> system has mechanical energy <math alttext="E sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> . Which of the following, if any, correctly compare <math alttext="E sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="E sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> ?

choices.label: <math alttext="E sub 1 is less than E sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>
<math alttext="E sub 1 equals E sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>
<math alttext="E sub 1 is greater than E sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>
The comparison cannot be made without knowing the relative values of the block masses and spring constants of the springs.

content.answer: The comparison cannot be made without knowing the relative values of the block masses and spring constants of the springs.

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
